title: Lauren Hard, Ronald Hernandez
description: The couple, who both attended Teaneck High School in Teaneck, N.J., began dating after seeing each other at a mutual friend’s going-away party in New York.
content: Lauren Hard and Ronald George Hernandez were married Feb. 28 at Liberty House Restaurant in Jersey City, N.J. The Rev. John M. O’Sullivan, affiliated with the Federation of Christian Ministries, officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kreda
title: The Islanders Are Saying Goodbye to Brooklyn
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Saturday that soon the team would again play all of its home games at Nassau Coliseum on Long Island until a new arena opens.
content: The Islanders will be returning full-time to Long Island a bit earlier than expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Mike Baker and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Trump Moves to Calm Fears as First U.S. Death From Coronavirus Is Reported
description: A person in the Seattle area has died, officials said. Mr. Trump called more cases “likely” but added that “there’s no reason to panic at all.”
content: WASHINGTON — Hours after officials confirmed the first death in the country from the coronavirus, President Trump moved on Saturday to calm public fears and demonstrate aggressive action against the illness, including by issuing new restrictions on foreign travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Dispatches from Elsewhere’ and ‘Doctor Who’
description: Jason Segel stars in a new anthology on AMC, while the 12th season of “Doctor Who” comes to a close on BBC America.
content: DISPATCHES FROM ELSEWHERE 10 p.m. on AMC. Fans of elaborate scavenger hunts would get a kick of out this new anthology series. The idea came to Jason Segel, the show’s creator and star, after he discovered an art project and immersive game that drew more than 7,000 people in San Francisco and Oakland from 2008 to 2011. He adapted it for the screen and plays one of four characters (along with Sally Field, André Benjamin and Eve Lindley) who are brought together by what is, at the outset, to some a practical joke and to others a global conspiracy. There’s an element of growth here: Along the way, the journey helps participants overcome inner battles. In a recent interview with The New York Times, Segel said the show celebrates regular people. “A lot of stories are about someone finding out that they’re extraordinary,” he said. “And this whole thing, it’s this idea that we can all be ordinary together and that it’s beautiful.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 1, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 1, 2020.
content: The illustrated Scratch column last Sunday, about the cost of various liquids, misstated the price for a gallon of maple syrup from Vermont Country Store. It is $119.80, not $239.60.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Only Drink My Coffee Black, and I Cannot Drink It With Sugar’
description: A morning routine, a Katharine Gibbs student goes to a show and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Mother and Daughter Attacked for Speaking Spanish, Prosecutor Says
description: Officials filed felony hate-crime charges against two women accused of assault in a Boston neighborhood, where more than half of the residents are Latino.
content: The mother and daughter were speaking Spanish while walking home from dinner in a Boston neighborhood, where more than half of the residents are Latino and more than half were born in another country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: In Trump’s Words: Praise for the Taliban and Optimism About the Coronavirus
description: President Trump found himself veering off message in discussing the two big news stories of the day: the signing of an agreement with the Taliban and the spread of the coronavirus.
content: On a day that saw the signing of a historic agreement with the Taliban and the first American death of the coronavirus outbreak, President Trump found himself veering off message on Saturday during both a news conference and a speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: In Trump’s Words: Praise for the Taliban and Optimism About the Coronavirus
description: President Trump found himself veering off message in discussing the two big news stories of the day: the signing of an agreement with the Taliban and the spread of the coronavirus.
content: On a day that saw the signing of a historic agreement with the Taliban and the first American death of the coronavirus outbreak, President Trump found himself veering off message on Saturday during both a news conference and a speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference.

author: By Deb Amlen
title: ‘Forget About It!’
description: To mark the beginning of Women’s History Month, Andrea Carla Michaels kicks off a week of puzzles made by women.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — March is Women’s History Month, and The New York Times, along with other puzzle destinations such as the AVCX crossword and Universal, is celebrating by publishing a series of crosswords made by women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: What Comes Next, Joe Biden?
description: He needs to capitalize on his big South Carolina win to stay competitive with Bernie Sanders.
content: Finally! Four states and nearly two months into the Democratic primary voting, Joe Biden scored a win. On Saturday, he received a big electoral kiss from South Carolina, where he captured 48 percent of the vote and at least 29 of 54 delegates (with more expected as the results were finalized). It was the largest margin of victory — and the largest single delegate haul — in the race thus far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Coronavirus, India Violence, South Carolina Primary: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Abortion Case in Colombia Could Be a Landmark in Latin America
description: A ruling in the case, which has reopened a fierce debate over the procedure’s legal and moral implications, could have repercussions across the region.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — A top court in Colombia is expected to rule in the coming days on whether to permit abortion during the first months of a pregnancy, a decision that could be a landmark in Latin America and have a ripple effect across a region known for its restrictive laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: How the Democrats’ ‘15% Rule’ Could Reshape the Race on Super Tuesday
description: The rule is intended to weed out candidates who don’t have a viable path to the nomination.
content: If you pay attention to the news ahead of Super Tuesday, you’re likely to hear about a critical bar that the candidates face, a baseline test that could reshape the large field of Democrats seeking the party’s nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: 5 Takeaways From the South Carolina Primary
description: Joe Biden is “very much alive,” but the race is far from over as the Democratic presidential candidates turn toward the 16 contests on Tuesday.
content: There was no drama this time, and no delay: Within one minute of the polls closing on Saturday, all the major networks called South Carolina for Joseph R. Biden Jr. It was the first state the former vice president has ever won in three presidential campaigns, and it was a landslide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Thomas Kaplan
title: A Virus Spreads, Stocks Fall, and Democrats See an Opening to Hit Trump
description: The president’s response to rising fears over coronavirus has given his would-be opponents a chance to attack his biggest strength with voters: economic stewardship.
content: WASHINGTON — Democratic presidential candidates have seized on President Trump’s response to the spreading global coronavirus outbreak, and the growing threat it poses to America’s record-long economic expansion, to attack the president on what has been his greatest strength with voters: the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Wall Street Has Lost Its Nerve. What Will It Take to Get It Back?
description: The S&P 500 just had its worst week in more than a decade as investors fretted over the global coronavirus outbreak. The best cure may be time.
content: Wall Street has often adopted a simple playbook when facing a stock market plunge: “Buy the dip.” Not lately.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Extend a Nuclear Arms Treaty
description: Andrei Kozyrev, former foreign minister of Russia, writes about the New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Sungjae Im Gets First PGA Tour Win at Honda Classic
description: The tour’s rookie of the year last season played a marathon schedule before becoming the youngest to ever win the tournament.
content: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Sungjae Im, a precocious 21-year-old from South Korea, has been playing professional golf in the United States since 2018. Im, however, does not own a home, rent an apartment or even spend a few weeks at an Airbnb in America, despite a 10-month playing schedule that includes prolonged breaks between tournaments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Former Barnard Student Accused of Killing Mother
description: A 22-year-old was living at home in New Jersey, and her mother wanted her to return to college. The argument ended in murder, court documents say.
content: Like many students who have decided to take a break from college, Malika Jones moved back home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles and Erika P. Rodriguez
title: Months After Puerto Rico Earthquakes, Thousands Are Still Living Outside
description: In the past week alone, the Puerto Rico Seismic Network registered 43 “significant” quakes, leaving many people fearful of going home. More than 8,000 houses have been damaged.
content: GUÁNICA, P.R. — Nearly two months after an earthquake sent the population of southwest Puerto Rico rushing into the streets, thousands of people are still slumbering each night under camping tents, on cots, in their cars and in enormous open tents that serve as government shelters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Amber Bloom, Dov Lebowitz-Nowak
description: He played an intellectual otter and she a dancing red bell pepper in the workshop of a new play.
content: Amber Bloom and Dov Lebowitz-Nowak were married Feb. 29 at the Prince George Ballroom in Manhattan. Rabbi Serge A. Lippe officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: At CPAC, Trump Takes Aim at Rivals
description: President Trump appeared eager to bask in the warm reception of a conservative audience, who spent the conference listening to speakers road-testing messages for his re-election campaign.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump crouched underneath his microphone on Saturday, mimicking the height of Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire former mayor of New York City who is running for president.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Starbucks Baristas Accuse Service Company of Abuse and Pay Gaps
description: A union representing employees at airport Starbucks locations says immigrant, transgender and black baristas have faced discrimination.
content: One transgender barista said his supervisors kept writing “Jessica” instead of Jay on his work schedule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Trip Gabriel
title: For Buttigieg, a Search for Black Support That Never Arrived
description: Facing better-known and better-financed opponents, Pete Buttigieg knew he would struggle to attract black voters in South Carolina. On Saturday his efforts came up empty.
content: SUMTER, S.C. — In October, Pete Buttigieg said he would do better with South Carolina’s black voters once they got to know him better.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 2, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Students
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: Defiant Iranian Directors Speak Out About Censorship, Onscreen and Off
description: Mohammad Rasoulof, whose new movie won the top prize at the Berlin Film Festival, is one of several filmmakers who have grown more outspoken as Iran clamps down on artistic expression.
content: When “There Is No Evil,” the new drama by the celebrated Iranian director Mohammad Rasoulof, debuted at the Berlin Film Festival on Friday, it was a bittersweet moment for Rasoulof.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How to Prepare for the Coronavirus
description: Coronavirus cases continued to be confirmed in the United States. By following some basic steps, you can help reduce your risk, and do your part to protect others, if your community is affected.
content: The coronavirus continues to spread in Asia, Europe and the Middle East, with more than 70 cases and two deaths confirmed in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Fear of Coronavirus Leaves the Faithful Without Mass in Italy’s North
description: Concerns over safety and the fear of spreading the virus have upended many rituals of life in the region, including Sunday Mass.
content: MILAN — The camera focused on a woman reading a prayer for people infected with the coronavirus, and for the doctors and nurses helping Italy deal with the largest outbreak in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: As Another Election Looms, Israelis Ponder Politics, and Contagion
description: At an airport outside Tel Aviv, some passengers worried about flying away from a big vote, and into an epidemic.
content: TEL AVIV — For passengers hurrying through the departures hall of Israel’s main airport on Sunday, many with their faces covered by masks, there was one big conundrum: Should they stay or should they go?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Marcus
title: What the Plague Can Teach Us About the Coronavirus
description: We need to be on guard against the xenophobia and persecution that arose during outbreaks of that dreaded disease.
content: The city that gave us the word quarantine nearly 600 years ago is once again facing an epidemic. On Feb. 23, officials in Venice canceled the final days of its Carnival festival, which brings hordes of tourists to the notoriously overcrowded lagoon city. The coronavirus Covid-19 had arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damon Winter and Joseph Kelly
title: Why South Carolina Was So Personal for Joe Biden
description: His old friends bucked him up on Saturday. Will it give him a charge for Super Tuesday? Here’s a look at scenes from the Palmetto State.
content: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Joe Biden scored a resounding victory in South Carolina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Greece Suspends Asylum as Turkey Opens Gates for Migrants
description: The military deployed troops to the Greek border with Turkey, warned migrants by text message not to cross and announced summary deportations.
content: ORESTIADA, Greece — Greece took a raft of tough measures Sunday as it tried to repel thousands of migrants amassed at its border with Turkey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Michael Bloomberg, a Billionaire Learning on the Job
description: He joked to a crowd in Denver that he would rather be at his house in Vail, and told people he was excited for “Super Bowl Tuesday.” But Mr. Bloomberg is getting a little bit better at this.
content: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — Consider it progress for a presidential candidate on a steep learning curve: Michael R. Bloomberg now thanks his hecklers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Photographs by Dan Balilty
title: Israeli Slugfest:The Campaign in Pictures
description: Benjamin Netanyahu and Benny Gantz, battling to break a yearlong stalemate, wind up in the mud.
content: JERUSALEM — Heading into the third Israeli election in a year, the candidates got desperate. And things got ugly.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Disclosure of Campaign Donors
description: Floyd Abrams, the constitutional lawyer, discusses disclosure obligations of large donors.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt
title: Afghanistan War Enters New Stage as U.S. Military Prepares to Exit
description: The deal signed on Saturday could have the United States conducting strikes to aid old enemies like the Taliban — or lead to a complete withdrawal from the country.
content: WASHINGTON — Intelligence briefers regularly present President Trump with a classified map of Afghanistan, usually the only report on the war he examines, displaying the strikes carried out in recent days and, critically, the number of Taliban and other militants killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Velvet Ropes, Inclusion and Kanye West in Paris
description: Who gets to be part of the gang? Who gets pushed out? Celine, Comme des Garçons and Balmain offer different answers.
content: PARIS — The weekend began in the gilded salons of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, a grand mid-19th-century building on the banks of the Seine where the foundation of the European Union was laid and where Friday night Diane von Furstenberg received the honor of the Chevalier de Legion d’Honneur from Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank, in recognition of Ms. von Furstenberg’s services to women and to the refurbishment of the Statue of Liberty. Symbol of freedom, tolerance, welcome, you know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: Intel’s Culture Needed Fixing. Its C.E.O. Is Shaking Things Up.
description: Robert Swan, who leads the world’s biggest chip maker, is pushing his 110,000 employees to confront internal problems more openly.
content: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Since last spring, workers at Intel who turned on their corporate laptops or wall displays inside the company’s more than 1,000 conference rooms have seen a new tagline: “One Intel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Isabel Kershner
title: Israel, ‘Start-up Nation,’ Groans Under Strains of Growth and Neglect
description: The election on Monday might break a yearlong political deadlock. But huge challenges in health, education and transit are decades in the making.
content: JERUSALEM — When the cosmetics salesman from Petah Tikva rolls his Toyota out of the driveway each morning, he does not worry about the Palestinians, the Trump Middle East plan or tensions with Iran — the issues most of the world thinks of when it thinks about Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Paris' Louvre Museum Closed as Staff Walk Out Over Coronavirus
description: Tourists and art lovers were unable to visit the Louvre in Paris on Sunday as workers staged a walkout at the world's most-visited museum after a staff meeting about the coronavirus outbreak.
content: PARIS — Tourists and art lovers were unable to visit the Louvre in Paris on Sunday as workers staged a walkout at the world's most-visited museum after a staff meeting about the coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Kobe Bryant’s Widow ‘Devastated’ by Reports That Deputies Shared Crash Photos
description: A lawyer for Vanessa Bryant said the sharing of the photos by deputies was “an unspeakable violation of human decency.”
content: Kobe Bryant’s widow was “absolutely devastated” by reports that Los Angeles County sheriff’s deputies had shared graphic photos of the helicopter crash scene where her husband, their 13-year-old daughter and seven others were killed, her lawyer said in a statement on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: After Factory Disaster, Bangladesh Made Big Safety Strides. Are the Bad Days Coming Back?
description: The Rana Plaza collapse, which killed over 1,100 garment workers, led to much better labor conditions. Now that legacy could be in jeopardy, as a power struggle unfolds over factory safety.
content: As she walked to her job as a garment worker, Rima Khatun was passing the Natural Sweater Village on the outskirts of Dhaka, Bangladesh, when a gas boiler exploded inside. A wall of the two-story factory crashed onto a nearby sidewalk, injuring 10 pedestrians.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Danielle Foster, Douglas Graham
description: The couple met in January 2017 at a neighborhood bar on the Upper East Side.
content: Danielle Rose Foster and Douglas Wesley Graham were married Feb. 29 at the Fairmont Washington D.C. Georgetown hotel. Darryl Graham, a brother of the groom, received authorization from the District of Columbia to officiate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Readiness of U.S. for an Epidemic Raises Fears About Shortages
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 1, 2020.
content: “The Chinese bought us a month of time to prepare ourselves by imposing these astonishing and draconian measures. Unfortunately, we didn’t make good use of that time and now we’re heading into a very dangerous situation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: The Week in Business: It Was All About the Coronavirus
description: I’m going to do my taxes this week. There, I said it. Maybe now I’ll actually follow through. Or I’ll spend the week wandering from supermarket to supermarket, stocking up on canned soup. The coronavirus has been rattling the business world since January, but this week was different: It sent the markets tumbling and now seems poised to disrupt every aspect of American life. Maybe we’ll all end up doing our taxes from the safety of a bunker. — David Yaffe-Bellany
content: I’m going to do my taxes this week. There, I said it. Maybe now I’ll actually follow through. Or I’ll spend the week wandering from supermarket to supermarket, stocking up on canned soup. The coronavirus has been rattling the business world since January, but this week was different: It sent the markets tumbling and now seems poised to disrupt every aspect of American life. Maybe we’ll all end up doing our taxes from the safety of a bunker. — David Yaffe-Bellany
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
title: Winning South Carolina, Biden Makes Case Against Sanders: ‘Win Big or Lose’
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. drew on his decades-long relationships and leveraged his close bond with black voters to wrap up a state long considered his stronghold.
content: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. scored a decisive victory in the South Carolina primary on Saturday, reviving his listing campaign and establishing himself as the leading contender to slow Senator Bernie Sanders as the turbulent Democratic race turns to a slew of coast-to-coast contests on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul and Matt Stevens
title: Tom Steyer Drops Out of 2020 Presidential Race
description: Mr. Steyer, the former hedge-fund executive, exited the race after a disappointing finish in South Carolina — a state where he had spent considerable resources and pinned the hopes of his campaign.
content: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Tom Steyer, the billionaire former hedge-fund executive whose prolific campaign spending altered the Democratic primary and allowed him to persist in the race, withdrew after an apparent third-place finish Saturday night in South Carolina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Maria Abi-Habib
title: In India, Modi’s Policies Have Lit a Fuse
description: Many Indians believed it was only a matter of time before Hindu nationalism provoked the kind of bloodshed that exploded in New Delhi.
content: NEW DELHI — This past week, as neighborhoods in India’s capital burned and religiously driven bloodletting consumed more than 40 lives, most of them Muslim, India’s government was quick to say that the violence was spontaneous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miroslava German Sirotnikova and Marc Santora
title: ‘Slovakia Has Woken Up’: Governing Party Suffers Decisive Election Defeat
description: The loss paves the way for a new governing coalition after the main opposition group ran a campaign under the slogan “Together Against the Mafia.”
content: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — The longtime governing party in Slovakia suffered a sweeping defeat in national elections on Saturday, paving the way for a new government coalition that promised to fight corruption and promote the rule of law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Fatima Faizi and Najim Rahim
title: Afghan Peace Plan Faces Its First Roadblock: Releasing Taliban Prisoners
description: Afghanistan’s president said he had not agreed to release up to 5,000 prisoners, as a deal between the United States and the Taliban appears to require.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration’s nascent deal to end the war in Afghanistan faced its first stumbling block on Sunday, the day after it was signed, over whether the Afghan government must release Taliban prisoners as part of the continuing negotiations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Why Some Suburban Women Are Wary of Bernie Sanders
description: Virginia’s shift to the Democrats has been led by suburban moderates, especially college-educated women. Some wonder whether Mr. Sanders is what they signed up for.
content: VIRGINIA BEACH — In the Trump era, the suburbs have been Democrats’ surprising superpower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Campbell Robertson and Sabrina Tavernise
title: How Coronavirus Is Already Being Viewed Through a Partisan Lens
description: Public health officials say that injecting politics into the growing outbreak could make it harder to fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: This Was Molly Seidel’s First Marathon. Her Next Will Be at the Olympics.
description: Seidel, 25, has two jobs, shares an apartment with her sister and runs turkey trots in costume. No, she can’t believe this is happening, either.
content: ATLANTA — Molly Seidel was ebullient when she qualified for the U.S. Olympic marathon trials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: Coronavirus in N.Y.: Panic Shopping for Masks, but Brunch Is Packed
description: The first case in New York City was confirmed Sunday night: a woman in her 30s who is isolated in her Manhattan home.
content: Some pharmacies are seeing huge queues of customers buying hand sanitizers and face masks. One newsstand owner is cleaning his hands obsessively with a bowl of warm water that he keeps inside his stall. A bar owner has written to the mayor to see whether the city can offer licenses for takeout cocktails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: This Was Molly Seidel’s First Marathon. Her Next Will Be at the Olympics.
description: Seidel, 25, has two jobs, shares an apartment with her sister and runs turkey trots in costume. No, she can’t believe this is happening, either.
content: ATLANTA — Molly Seidel was ebullient when she qualified for the U.S. Olympic marathon trials.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Second Death From Virus Is Reported in the U.S.
description: The second death was a man in his 70s in the Seattle area who had underlying health conditions.
content: A second person has died of the novel coronavirus in the Seattle area and more confirmed cases of the illness have emerged in Washington State, officials said Sunday evening. Public health leaders in King County, Wash., said a man in his 70s with underlying health conditions died on Saturday at EvergreenHealth hospital in Kirkland. That’s the same facility where officials identified the nation’s first coronavirus death on Saturday — a man in his 50s with underlying health conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller, Sarah Kliff and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Avoiding Coronavirus May Be a Luxury Some Workers Can’t Afford
description: A sick day? Remote work? Not so easy if your job is at a restaurant, a day care center or a construction site.
content: Stay home from work if you get sick. See a doctor. Use a separate bathroom from the people you live with. Prepare for schools to close, and to work from home. These are measures the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has recommended to slow a coronavirus outbreak in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Coronavirus and the Workplace: What if the Boss Says to Stay Home?
description: Businesses are grappling with how to deal with a potential outbreak. Here’s what they’re doing, and how it could affect their workers.
content: Furloughs. Sick leave. Working from home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart and Jesse Drucker
title: Milken Had Key Allies in Pardon Bid: Trump’s Inner Circle
description: Rudolph Giuliani and Sheldon Adelson were among those who asked President Trump to pardon a symbol of 1980s greed.
content: Michael Milken, a symbol of 1980s greed who went to prison for securities fraud and conspiracy, was at home in Encino, Calif., on Feb. 18 when he got a phone call from the White House. President Trump was on the line with good news: Mr. Milken had been pardoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: The Met Opera’s ‘Dutchman’ Sails Into Port With a New Star
description: Its director, François Girard, is becoming the company’s go-to for Wagner, with “Lohengrin” to come.
content: At a rehearsal one recent afternoon, the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra was roaring out the final scene of Wagner’s “Der Fliegende Holländer” (“The Flying Dutchman”), which opens on Monday, the first new Met production of the work in over 30 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Trip Gabriel
title: Pete Buttigieg Drops Out of Democratic Presidential Race
description: The first openly gay major presidential candidate, Mr. Buttigieg rose to the primary’s top tier, but was unable to build a broad coalition of voters, and lost badly in South Carolina Saturday.
content: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  — Pete Buttigieg, the former small-city Indiana mayor and first openly gay major presidential candidate, said Sunday night he was dropping out of the Democratic race, following a crushing loss in the South Carolina primary where his poor performance with black Democrats signaled an inability to build a broad coalition of voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Invisible Man’ Tops Box Office, Giving New Life to Old Monsters
description: A low-budget reboot of the 87-year-old movie character collected $29 million, unseating “Sonic the Hedgehog.”
content: LOS ANGELES — As it turns out, old monsters can perform new tricks: After stumbling with “The Mummy” in 2017, Universal Pictures shifted strategies and succeeded over the weekend in rebooting “The Invisible Man,” which was No. 1 at theaters in the United States and Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Esther Gibofsky, Adam Rattner
description: Their first date was at a bagel shop one morning, around 6, before they each headed to work.
content: Esther Rachel Gibofsky and Adam Charles Rattner were married Feb. 29 at Guastavino’s, an events space in Manhattan. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Meredith Perry, Amit Bedi
description: The couple met in March 2011 at a housewarming party in New York, which was hosted by their mutual friends.
content: Meredith Cramer Perry and Amit Kumar Bedi were married Feb. 29 at the Van Benthuysen-Elms Mansion, an events space in New Orleans. Michelle Brous, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated along with Warren Reed, another friend of the couple.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Thomas Schultz, Robert Blalock
description: The couple met in 2014 at a mutual friend’s home in Los Angeles.
content: Thomas McIntyre Schultz and Robert Scot Blalock were married Feb. 28 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Zuleima Astol, a member of the New York City clerk’s office, officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Avy Villaraza, Darnell Thompson
description: The couple met as parishioners at Harvest City Church in 2011.
content: Avy Villaraza and Darnell Xavier Thompson are to be married March 1 at Saddle Creek, an events space in Dripping Springs, Texas. Jonathan C. Clatt, who is the lead pastor at Harvest City Church in San Antonio, is to officiate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ainara Tiefenthäler
title: Joe Biden Lands First Big Primary Win
description: The former vice president energized his campaign with a big win in South Carolina. And Bernie Sanders, who came in a distant second, had his largest loss so far.
content: The former vice president energized his campaign with a big win in South Carolina. And Bernie Sanders, who came in a distant second, had his largest loss so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez
title: An Office With 128,000 Miles
description: As a reporter covering Texas, I ate, worked and slept in my trusty, company-issued Chevy. So allow me a moment to observe the end of its road.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.HOUSTON — In five years and eight months, I put 128,000 miles on my car. I have covered Texas for The New York Times for more than eight years. That means my car — a 2014 Chevrolet Malibu four-door sedan — covered Texas, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Alaïa and Lagerfeld: The Lives of Very Different Men
description: One designer was independent, the other aligned with major houses. But new books show both had an outsize effect on fashion.
content: People in fashion are obsessed with time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Dawn Perry makes the case for boneless chicken breasts in three recipes. Make one — or all three — in the days to come.
content: Good morning. Dawn Perry makes the case for boneless chicken breasts this week in The Times. It’s a controversial point of view in our thigh-centric world, but it’s powerful nonetheless and, in Dawn’s hands, delicious to boot. Don’t think of chicken breasts as bland, she argues, so much as neutral in flavor, a blank canvas for spices and marinades. Don’t think of them as easy to overcook. Think of them as quick-cooking instead, the perfect partner in the preparation of an easy worknight meal. Yes, there are recipes attached to her argument! Maybe one of them is your dinner tonight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Making a Plague Movie, With Coronavirus on the Doorstep
description: A British film crew shooting in Italy suddenly found concern about the coronavirus encroaching, including a text from the director’s mother.
content: LONDON — Last Saturday, Nicholas Hulbert, a British film director, flew from London to Venice for his latest project.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Givenchy :Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Givenchy: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Givenchy: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wendy Moonan
title: A Painter and Social Activist With an ‘Unruly Nature’
description: Mary Lovelace O’Neal returns to New York at 78 with a solo show and an undimmed aversion to being pigeonholed.
content: The idea was born in an instant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Turkey Declares Major Offensive Against Syrian Government
description: After suffering its worst casualties in years, Turkey is openly declaring war against the Syrian government of Bashar al-Assad.
content: ISTANBUL — Turkey said on Sunday that it was launching a major counteroffensive against the Syrian government, for the first time openly declaring war on the government of Bashar al-Assad and steeply escalating Ankara’s involvement in Syria’s nine-year war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Bernie Sanders Raised $46 Million in February, a Record for 2020
description: Mr. Sanders’s campaign said that it had received 2.2 million donations in the month. Elizabeth Warren’s team announced raising $29 million over the same period.
content: Senator Bernie Sanders announced on Sunday that he had raised $46.5 million in February, a sum that gives him a significant financial advantage over all of his rivals aside from the self-funding billionaire Michael R. Bloomberg as the number of states holding primaries expands widely in March, beginning on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: ‘Bloody Sunday’ Commemoration Draws Democratic Candidates to Selma
description: Several of the presidential hopefuls walked across the Alabama bridge where civil rights protesters were brutally attacked 55 years ago.
content: SELMA, Ala. — Presidential candidates and prominent social justice activists descended on Alabama on Sunday to commemorate the anniversary of the brutal attack on civil rights marchers here in 1965, one of the most violent episodes in the struggle for black participation in democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elias E. Lopez
title: Ernesto Cardenal, Nicaraguan Priest, Poet and Revolutionary, Dies at 95
description: Father Cardenal defied the Roman Catholic Church in the 1980s by serving as a minister in the revolutionary government of Nicaragua.
content: The Rev. Ernesto Cardenal, one of Latin America’s most admired poets and priests, who defied the Roman Catholic Church in the 1980s by serving in the revolutionary Sandinista government of Nicaragua, died on Sunday in Managua, Nicaragua. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: At Olympic Marathon Trials, the Agony of Fourth Place
description: Des Linden, in the women’s division, and Leonard Korir, in the men’s, were favorites to make the U.S. team. They finished fourth, which can be the worst pain of all.
content: ATLANTA — The moments that Des Linden wants back came with about three and a half miles left in the race on Saturday as she battled wind gusts and the punishing hills at the U.S. Olympic marathon team trials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Italian League Postpones Matches Amid Coronavirus Crisis
description: Five games scheduled for this weekend in the top tier of the Italian were postponed on Saturday in an attempt to contain the coronavirus outbreak.
content: Italian soccer teams and Serie A’s governing body are squabbling with each other about when to play games, with Inter Milan’s chief executive, Giuseppe Marotta, saying the season even runs the risk of being unable to finish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Texas’s Lone G.O.P. Woman in Congress Faces a Stiff Challenge From the Right
description: Representative Kay Granger is in an expensive primary battle while facing accusations that she has not done enough for President Trump, who endorsed her.
content: FORT WORTH — On the heated upstairs patio of a downtown bar on a recent Friday night, dozens of Republican voters drank beers, snacked on nachos and cheered and sang along to the chorus of a disparaging ode to a liberal RINO — Republican in name only — from the swamp, who, according to the lyrics, had declared: “I’m Never Trump — you’ll never build that wall.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink and Mike Baker
title: Coronavirus May Have Spread in U.S. for Weeks, Gene Sequencing Suggests
description: Two cases detected weeks apart in Washington State had genetic links, suggesting that many more people in the area may be infected.
content: Researchers who have examined the genomes of two coronavirus infections in Washington State say the similarities between the cases suggest that the virus may have been spreading in the state for weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Battle for Control of Senate Takes Shape as Both Parties Seek Firewall
description: Democrats increasingly regard winning the Senate as their last remaining check on President Trump, should he win re-election, while Republicans fight to maintain power in Congress.
content: WASHINGTON — The 2020 battle for control of the Senate gets underway in earnest Tuesday, with both parties increasingly seeing the chamber as a must-win prize to guard against uncertainty over who will wind up in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times
